name: Recipe project
body:
Recipes from history

Custard Sauce

I am a enthusiastic history buff and amateur cook. I will be listing some of my favorite recipes from the days of yore. To begin with, I'll start off with a simple custard sauce from eighteenth century England, although you will find that there is not much difference with modern cusatard sauces today. The addition of rose water, which adds a nice floral note tot he sauce, is the main difference you might notice with modern sauces of this kind.

Ingredients

  • 4 egg yolks
  • 1/4 cup sugar
  • pinch of salt
  • 1 3/4 cup milk
  • 1/4 cup heavy cream
  • 4 drops rose water
  • 1 1/2 tbsp brandy

Method

  1. In the top of a double boiler, beat the eggs yolks with the sugar and the salt.
  2. Add the milk and the cream and stir well.
  3. Set the pot over (not in) gently boiling water and cook, stirring constantly, until the custard is thick enough to coate the back of a spoon (about 10 minutes).
  4. Remove from heat and stir in the rose water and brandy

Note: This sauce can be served hot or cold. It will thicken as it cools.
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
